On day 0, all mice were challenged intranasally with either ragweed (5µg/50µl saline) or saline (50 µl). Six hrs after challenge, lungs were harvested, snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen, and stored at -80°C for later use. Total RNA was isolated using RNeasy mini kits (Qiagen Inc., Valencia, CA). The RNA samples were DNAse-treated (Roche Diagnostics, Mannheim, Germany) and converted into cDNA using Superscript II Rnase H-Reverse Transcriptase (Invitrogen, Rockville, MD) according to previously published methods (Scheerens et al., Eur. J. of Immunology 2001, 31:1465-74).

In each cDNA sample, mRNA expression levels of a variety of genes were measured using real-time quantitative PCR (ABI Prism 5700, Perkin Elmer Applied Biosystems) and SYBR green (Qiagen Inc., Valencia, CA). Sense and antisense primers used for detection were developed in house and included primer sets to Th2-cytokines, chemokines, and various other molecules involved in airway inflammation. In addition to the gene of interest, in each sample the mRNA expression of a house keeping gene was measured (in this case ubiquitin). After correcting for the amount of RNA per sample, all data were calculated relative to the expression of the house keeping gene (represented as gene/ubiquitin ratio).

Results: In Figure 1, six genes essential for the development of a Th2-type airway inflammatory response are depicted and data are expressed as gene/ubiquitin ratio. The data demonstrate that intranasal challenge with ragweed in sensitized mice upregulated mRNA expression levels of Th2-genes such as IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 when compared to saline-challenged mice (ragweed-challenged mice denoted as RW/RW/Saline in grey bars, saline-challenged mice denoted as RW/Saline/Saline in open bars). In addition, mRNA expression levels of the chemokines TARC, MDC and eotaxin were upregulated after allergen challenge in the RW/RW/Saline mice. In contrast, in mice pretreated with 1018 ISS (denoted as RW/RW/1018 in black bars), the ragweed-induced upregulation of the various cytokines and chemokines expression levels was inhibited, however, only when 1018 ISS pretreatment was given on day -1 or on day -3, or for some genes on day -5.

In figure 2, gene/ubiquitin ratios are shown for GOB-5 and C2. GOB-5 and C2 (also known as FIZZ-1) are both genes that are known to be induced in the airways by IL-4. It is clear from our data that challenge with ragweed led to upregulation of both genes. In contrast, pretreatment with 1018 ISS given a few days before the challenge with ragweed inhibited the expression of these mRNAs associated with a Th2-type airway inflammation. For GOB-5, 1018 ISS treatment is effective when given on day -1 or day -3. For C2, 1018 ISS treatment is effective when given on day -3 or day -5.

It has been published that pretreatment with ISS inhibits allergen-induced airway eosinophilia and airway hypen-esponsiveness in a mouse model for allergic asthma (Broide et al., J. Immunol., 161:7054, 1998). We have shown that this inhibition correlates with ISS-induced down-regulation of Th2 and Th2-dependent gene expression levels in the airways (Hessel et al. (2005) J. Exp. Med., 202(11):1563.

Here, we determined the duration of ISS-mediated inhibition of the allergen-induced Th2 response in the airways. As a way to establish this window of effectiveness, we measured the expression of a series of genes in the airways that are essential in or closely related to the development of Th2-type airway inflammation after allergen challenge in sensitized mice. Our data demonstrate that 1018 ISS given between one to three days before the allergen challenge is able to inhibit the majority of these genes, which results in a greatly diminished Th2 response in the airways. If 1018 ISS is given further removed from the allergen challenge (i.e., earlier than day -3), we found that 1018 IS8 is not able to down-regulate Th2 or Th2-dependent gene expression.

Thus, if one seeks to study the direct effects of ISS treatment on the airway Th2 response, it is advisable to pretreat within one to three days before the allergen challenge, whereas if one is interested in studying the long-term effects of ISS on disease modification, it is advisable to wait at least a week after ISS treatment to ensure the absence of direct ISS effects.

heading.u: Example 2 The effects of long-term intranasal treatment with 1018 ISS in a mouse model for ragweed-induced allergic asthma.

description.p: One purpose of this set of experiments is to investigate whether long-term intranasal treatment with 1018 ISS leads to disease modification in a mouse model for ragweed-induced allergic asthma. The long-term effects of weekly intranasal treatment with 1018 ISS in ragweed-sensitized and challenged mice were investigated.

Mice were sensitized and subsequently challenged with an intranasal low dose of ragweed on a weekly basis. Also on a weekly basis the mice were treated intranasally with either saline or 1018 ISS. At several time points during the course of the experiment, mice were set aside to rest for a period of 2 weeks. This rest period was to ensure that the direct effects of 1018 ISS treatment had waned. At the end of the 2 weeks, these mice were re-challenged with a high dose of ragweed and the response to this allergen challenge was evaluated by ways of measuring the amount of Th2 and Th1 cytokines in the airways and by determining the amount of airway eosinophil infiltration.

More specifically, the materials used were: 1018 (lot number AGU-003, Dynavax); Ragweed (Pollen lot #16, 24QQ 56-9FD-3, extract 17 Jan 03, Dynavax); pyrogenic-free saline (Sigma). The methods used were as follows: The study was performed with 6-8 week old female BALB/c mice from Charles River (Hollister, CA). The mice were intraperitoneally sensitized with 15 µg of ragweed on Alum on day 0 and day 7. Starting from day 14 onwards, mice were challenged intranasally on a weekly basis with 0.5 µg ragweed or pyrogenic-free saline (50 µl) under light isofloraine anesthesia. Simultaneously, the mice were treated weekly with 1018 ISS (20µg/50µl saline) or pyrogenic-free saline (50 µl) via the intranasal route. After 1, 2, 6, and after 10 weeks of antigen challenge and ISS treatment, mice were set aside for a rest period of 2 weeks and subsequently re-challenged intranasally with 5 µg of ragweed. Twenty-four hrs later lungs were lavaged and cytokines were measured in the lavage fluid by ELISA. The detection levels for the IL-4, IL-13, IL-10, and IFN-γ ELISA were respectively 8, 8, 8, and 23 pg/ml. Lavage fluid was spun down and the cells recovered were counted using trypan blue. The remaining cells were used to prepare a cytospin and stained with Wright-Giemsa staining. Differential cell counts were performed and the number of eosinophils was determined for each cytospin.

In Figure 3 and 4, levels of the Th2-type cytokines IL-4, IL-13 and IL-10 measured in lavage fluid (BAL fluid) are depicted in pg/ml. In addition, in Figure 4 the Th1-type cytokine IFN-γ is shown. The results indicate that weekly challenges with ragweed in sensitized mice led to a robust Th2 inflammation in the airways with high levels of IL-4, IL-13, and IL-10, as well as a high number of eosinophils (shown in Figure 5). These high levels of Th2 cytokines and eosinophils were absent when ragweed-sensitized mice were challenged with saline only. When mice were challenged with ragweed and simultaneously treated with 1018 ISS, no significant differences were observed after 1, 2, or 6 weeks of ISS treatment when comparing ragweed-challenged mice treated with saline or with ISS. However, after 10 weeks of 1018 ISS treatment, the Th2 cytokine levels as well as the number of eosinophils were significantly diminished (IL-13: * p<0.05; IL-4, IL-10, and eosinophils: ** p<0.01), indicating that the Th2 inflammation was inhibited in those mice. Furthermore, these data show that no increased levels of IFN-γ were induced in the mice treated with 1018 ISS at any of the time points measured, indicating that 10 weekly treatments with 1018 ISS did not induce an overt Th1-type response in the airways.

Our experimental data described in this experiment demonstrated that ISS treatments did lead to disease modification, i.e. inhibition of the Th2 response to allergen, however, this was in our hands not accompanied by the development of an overt Th1 response in the airways. In Example 1, we determined that the direct effects of 1018 ISS on the Th2 response in the airways lasted less than a week. Therefore, in this Example, all mice were rested for at least 2 weeks after their last ISS treatment, before being re-challenged with allergen. Thus any effects seen could not be attributed direct effects of ISS treatment. The response to the re-challenge with allergen was to determine whether the airways would still develop a Th2 inflammation in response to the allergen challenge or whether they had become refractory to allergen challenge. Our data showed that at least 10 weekly intranasal 1018 ISS treatments was needed to achieve this disease modifying effect.

heading.u: Example 3 The effects of long-term intranasal treatment with 1018 ISS in a mouse model for ragweed-induced allergic asthma

description.p: This set of experiments was conducted to investigate whether long-term intranasal treatment with 1018 ISS conferred disease modification in a mouse model for ragweed-induced allergic asthma and to evaluate whether this disease modification persists after 1018 ISS treatment is stopped but allergen exposure is continued.

Mice were sensitized and subsequently challenged with an intranasal low dose of ragweed on a weekly basis. Also on a weekly basis the mice were treated intranasally with either saline or 1018 ISS. At several time points during the course of the experiment, mice were set aside to rest for a period of 2 weeks. This rest period was to ensure that the direct effects of 1018 ISS treatment had waned. At the end of the 2 weeks, these mice were re-challenged with a high dose of ragweed and the response to this allergen challenge was evaluated by ways of measuring the amount of Th2 and Th1 cytokines in the airways. The experimental groups included in this study were as follows:
sensitizationweekly allergenweekly treatment
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed wk 1-25saline week 1-25
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed wk 1-251018 ISS week 1-25
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed wk 1-251018 ISS week 1-12
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed wk 1-121018 ISS week 1-12

The purpose of the mice receiving ISS treatment for 12 weeks and allergen challenges for a total of 25 weeks was to evaluate whether ISS-induced disease modification was long-lasting in the presence of continued allergen exposure.

More specifically, the materials used were: 1018 (lot number AGU-003, Dynavax); Ragweed (Pollen lot # 01/26/05, Dynavax); pyrogenic-free saline (Sigma). The study was performed with 6-8 week old female BALB/c mice from Charles River (Hollister, CA). The mice were intraperitoneally sensitized with 15 µg of ragweed on Alum on day 0 and day 7. Starting from day 14 onwards, mice were challenged intranasally on a weekly basis with 0.5 µg ragweed or pyrogenic-free saline (50 µl) under light isofloraine anesthesia. Simultaneously, the mice were treated weekly with 1018 ISS (20µg/50µl saline) or TOLAMBA (20µg/50µl saline) or pyrogenic-free saline (50 µl) via the intranasal route. After 1, 8, 12, 16, and after 25 weeks of antigen challenges and ISS treatment, mice were set aside for a rest period of 2 weeks and subsequently re-challenged intranasally with 5 µg of ragweed. Twenty-four hours later lungs were lavaged and cytokines were measured in the lavage fluid by ELISA.

Results: In Figure 6, levels of the Th2-type cytokines IL-4, IL-5, IL-13 and IL-10 measured in lavage fluid (BAL fluid) are depicted in pg/ml. The detection levels for the IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, IL-10, and IFN-γ ELISA were respectively 8, 8, 8, 8, and 23 pg/ml. In addition, the Th1-type cytokine IFN-γ was measured but no induction of IFN-γ above detection level was measured in any of the treatment groups. Our results show that weekly challenges with ragweed in sensitized mice led to a robust Th2 inflammation in the airways with high levels of IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, and IL-10. When mice were challenged with ragweed and simultaneously treated with 1018 ISS, no significant differences were observed after 1 week of ISS treatment when comparing ragweed-challenged mice treated with saline or with ISS. However, after 8, 12, 16, and 25 weeks of 1018 ISS treatment, the Th2 cytokine levels were significantly diminished, indicating that the allergen-induced Th2 inflammation was inhibited in the 1018 ISS-treated mice. The observation that no detectable levels of IFN-γ were induced in the mice treated with 1018 ISS at any of the time points measured indicates that 25 weekly treatments with 1018 ISS did not induce an overt Th1-type response in the airways. In groups treated for 12 weeks with 1018 ISS that subsequently continued to receive allergen challenges for another 13 weeks, the Th2 response remained inhibited, indicating that the disease modification induced by 1018 ISS is long-lasting.

In Example 2, we demonstrated that 10 weekly ISS treatments led to disease modification, i.e., inhibition of the Th2 response to allergen, however, this was not accompanied by the development of an overt Th1 response in the airways. The experiment described here extends this finding with the observation that disease modification is in fact already achieved after 8 weekly 1018 ISS treatments and that this disease modification persists even when allergen exposures continued for another 13 weeks.

Methods similar to Example 3 above were used except that both 1018 ISS and 1018 ISS conjugated to Amb a I (conjugate known as TOLAMBA) were used. Figure 7 is a graph that depicts the results of measuring Th2-type cytokines, IL-4, IL-5, IL-10, and IL-13 in mice that have been treated with 20 µg of 1018 ISS via the intranasal route on a weekly basis for 25 weeks or 20 µg TOLAMBA via the intranasal route on a weekly basis for 25 weeks. Th2 suppression was also observed when using ISS-conjugate.

heading.u: Example 5 The effects of long-term intranasal treatment with 1018 ISS in a mouse model for ragweed-induced allergic asthma and the role of IFN-γ

description.p: This experiment was conducted to investigate whether the maintenance of the disease modification induced by long-term intranasal treatment with 1018 ISS in a mouse model for ragweed-induced allergic asthma was mediated by the cytokine IFN-γ.

Mice were sensitized and subsequently challenged with an intranasal low dose of ragweed on a weekly basis. Also on a weekly basis the mice were treated intranasally with either saline or 1018 ISS. At several time points during the course of the experiment, mice were set aside to rest for a period of 2 weeks. This rest period was to ensure that the direct effects of 1018 ISS treatment had waned. At the end of the 2 weeks, these mice were re-challenged with a high dose of ragweed and the response to this allergen challenge was evaluated by ways of measuring the amount of Th2 and Th1 cytokines in the airways. The experimental groups included in this study were as follows:
sensitizationweekly allergenweekly treatmentantibody treatment
ragweed day 0 and 7saline wk 1-17saline week 1-17none
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed 1-17saline week 1-17none
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed 1-171018 ISS week 1-17none
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed 1-171018 ISS week 1-13none
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed 1-131018 ISS week 1-13none
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed 1-171018 ISS week 1-13isotype (GL113) wk 13-17
ragweed day 0 and 7ragweed 1-171018 ISS week 1-13anti-IFN-g (XMG1.2) wk 13-17

The purpose of the mice receiving ISS treatment for 13 weeks and allergen challenges for a total of 17 weeks was to evaluate whether ISS-induced disease modification was long-lasting in the presence of continued allergen exposure. The purpose of the groups receiving antibody treatment (either control or anti-IFN-γ antibodies) was to evaluate whether IFN-γ was necessary for the maintenance of the ISS-induced disease modification.

More specifically, the materials used were: 1018 ISS (lot number AGU-003, Dynavax); Ragweed (Pollen lot # 01/26/05, Dynavax); pyrogenic-free saline (Sigma). The study was performed with 6-8 week old female BALB/c mice from Charles River (Hollister, CA). The mice were intraperitoneally sensitized with 15 µg of ragweed on Alum on day 0 and day 7. Starting from day 14 onwards, mice were challenged intranasally on a weekly basis with 0.5 µg ragweed or pyrogenic-free saline (50 µl) under light isofloraine anesthesia. Simultaneously, the mice were treated weekly with 1018 ISS (20µg/50µl saline) or pyrogenic-free saline (50 µl) via the intranasal route. In some groups mice were intraperitoneally treated with isotype control antibodies (clone GL113) or with antibodies to IFN-γ (clone XMG1.2) (2 mg in 200 µl, once per week) during week 13-17. After 1, 3, 8, 13, and 17 weeks of antigen challenges and ISS treatment, mice were set aside for a rest period of 2 weeks and subsequently re-challenged intranasally with 5 µg of ragweed. Twenty-four hours later lungs were lavaged and cytokines were measured in the lavage fluid by ELISA.

Results: In Figure 8, levels of the Th2-type cytokines IL-4, IL-13 and IL-5 measured in lavage fluid (BAL fluid) are depicted in pg/ml. The detection levels for the IL-4, IL-13, IL-5, and IFN-γ ELISA were respectively 16, 16, 31, and 16 pg/ml. In addition, the Th I-type cytokine IFN-γ was measured but no induction of IFN-γ above detection level was measured in any of the treatment groups. Our results show that weekly challenges with ragweed in sensitized mice led to a robust Th2 inflammation in the airways with high levels of IL-4, IL-13, and IL-5. When mice were challenged with ragweed and simultaneously treated with 1018 ISS, no significant differences in IL-4 and IL-5 were observed after 1 or 3 weeks of ISS treatment when comparing ragweed-challenged mice treated with saline or with ISS. IL-13 levels were significantly inhibited in ISS-treated and ragweed-challenged mice after 1 or 3 weeks of ISS-treatment. After 8, 13, and 17 weeks of 1018 ISS treatment, however, all three Th2 cytokine levels were significantly diminished, indicating that the allergen-induced Th2 inflammation was inhibited in the 1018 ISS-treated mice. The observation that no detectable levels of IFN-γ were induced in the mice treated with 1018 ISS at any of the time points measured indicates that 17 weekly treatments with 1018 ISS did not induce an overt Th1-type response in the airways. In groups treated for 13 weeks with 1018 ISS that subsequently continued to receive allergen challenges for another 4 weeks, the Th2 response remained inhibited, indicating that the disease modification induced by 1018 ISS is long-lasting. In groups that were treated for 13 weeks with 1018 ISS, subsequently continued with allergen exposures and were treated with either control or anti-IFN-γ antibodies the Th2 response remained inhibited as well, indicating that IFN-γ is not necessary for the maintenance of disease modification.

In Example 2, we demonstrated that 10 weekly ISS treatments led to disease modification, i.e., inhibition of the Th2 response to allergen, however, this was not accompanied by the development of an overt Th1 response in the airways. In Example 3 we demonstrated that disease modification is already achieved after 8 weekly 1018 ISS treatments and that this disease modification persists even when allergen exposures continued for another 13 weeks. This experiment repeats the observation that disease modification is achieved after 8 weekly 1018 ISS treatments and extends it with the observation that IFN-γ is not needed for the maintenance of this disease modification.

claim.claim-text: Zusammensetzung, umfassend eine wirksame Menge einer immunstimulatorischen Sequenz (ISS), wobei die ISS eine CpG enthaltende ISS ist, zur Verwendung in der langfristigen Krankheitsmodifikation von Asthma durch Vielfach-Verabreichung dieser Zusammensetzung, wobei die ISS wenigstens 5-mal verabreicht wird.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß Anspruch 1, wobei die ISS wenigstens 8-mal verabreicht wird.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß Anspruch 1 oder 2, wobei die vielfachen Verabreichungen auf einer wöchentlichen Basis erfolgen.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß Anspruch 1 oder 2, wobei die vielfachen Verabreichungen alle zwei Wochen erfolgen.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß einem der vorangehenden Ansprüche, wobei die langfristige Krankheitsmodifikation eine Abnahme der Th2-Antwort in dem Individuum ist.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß Anspruch 5, wobei die Abnahme der Th2-Antwort in dem Individuum eine Verminderung irgendeines der Zytokine, ausgewählt aus IL-4, IL-5, IL-10 und IL-13, ist.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß Anspruch 5, wobei die Abnahme der Th2-Antwort in einem Individuum eine Verminderung der eosinophilen Infiltration in die Luftwege ist.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß einem der vorangehenden Ansprüche, wobei die Modifikation bis wenigstens 8 Wochen nach der letzten Verabreichung der ISS anhält.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß einem der vorangehenden Ansprüche, wobei die langfristige Krankheitsmodifikation bis wenigstens 13 Wochen nach der letzten Verabreichung der ISS anhält.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß einem der vorangehenden Ansprüche, wobei die Behandlung zu einer langfristigen Krankheitsmodifikation von Asthma führt, wobei das Asthma allergisches Asthma ist.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß einem der vorangehenden Ansprüche, wobei die ISS die 1018 ISS ist.

Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß einem der Ansprüche 1 bis 10, wobei die ISS 5'-Nx(TCG(Nq))yNw(X1X2CGX2'X1'(CG)p)z ist, worin N Nukleoside mit x = 0-3, y = 1-4, w = -2, -1, 0, 1 oder 2, p = 0 oder 1, q = 0, 1 oder 2, und z = 1-20 sind, worin X1 und X1', X2 und X2' selbstkomplementär sind und worin das 5' T der (TCG(Nq))y-Sequenz 0-3 Basen vom 5'-Ende des Polynukleotids entfernt ist.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß einem der vorangehenden Ansprüche, wobei die ISS unkonjugierte ISS ist.
Zusammensetzung zur Verwendung gemäß einem der vorangehenden Ansprüche, wobei die ISS Phosphorthioat-Verknüpfungen umfasst.

A composition comprising an effective amount of an immunostimulatory sequence (ISS) wherein the ISS is a CpG containing ISS for use in the long term disease modification of asthma by multiple administration of said composition, wherein the ISS is administered at least 5 times.
The composition for use according to claim 1, wherein the ISS is administered at least 8 times.
The composition for use according to claim 1 or 2, wherein the multiple administrations occur on a weekly basis.
The composition for use according to claim 1 or 2, wherein the multiple administrations occur every two weeks.
The composition for use according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the long term disease modification is a decrease of Th2 response in the individual.
The composition for use according to claim 5, wherein the decrease of Th2 response in the individual is a decrease of any one of the cytokines selected from IL-4, IL-5, IL-10, and IL-13.
The composition for use according to claim 5, wherein the decrease of Th2 response in an individual is a decrease in eosinophil infiltration in the airways.
The composition for use according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein modification lasts at least 8 weeks after the last administration of the ISS.
The composition for use according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the long term disease modification lasts at least 13 weeks after the last administration of the ISS.
The composition for use according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the treatment results in long term disease modification of asthma wherein the asthma is allergic asthma.
The composition for use according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the ISS is 1018 ISS.

The composition for use according to any one of claims 1 to 10, wherein the ISS is 5'-Nx(TCG(Nq))yNw(X1X2CGX2'X1'(CG)p)z wherein N are nucleosides with x = 0-3, y = 1-4, w = -2, -1, 0, 1 or 2, p= 0 or 1, q = 0, 1 or 2, and z = 1-20, wherein X1 and X1', X2 and X2' are self-complimentary, and wherein the 5' T of the (TCG(Nq))y sequence is 0-3 bases from the 5' end of the polynucleotide.
The composition for use according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the ISS is unconjugated ISS.
The composition for use according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the ISS comprises phosphorothioate linkages.

Composition comprenant une quantité efficace d'une séquence immunostimulante (ISS) où l'ISS est une ISS contenant CpG destinée à être utilisée dans la modification de maladie à long terme de l'asthme par administration multiple de ladite composition, où l'ISS est administrée au moins 5 fois.
Composition destinée à être utilisée selon la revendication 1, où l'ISS est administrée au moins 8 fois.
Composition destinée à être utilisée selon la revendication 1 ou 2, où les administrations multiples ont lieu sur une base hebdomadaire.
Composition destinée à être utilisée selon la revendication 1 ou 2, où les administrations multiples ont lieu toutes les deux semaines.
Composition destinée à être utilisée selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, où la modification de maladie à long terme est une diminution de la réponse Th2 chez l'individu.

Composition destinée à être utilisée selon la revendication 5, où la diminution de la réponse Th2 chez l'individu est une diminution de l'une quelconque des cytokines choisies parmi IL-4, IL-5, IL-10 et IL-13.
Composition destinée à être utilisée selon la revendication 5, où la diminution de la réponse Th2 chez un individu est une diminution de l'infiltration des éosinophiles dans les voies aériennes.
Composition destinée à être utilisée selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, où la modification dure au moins 8 semaines après la dernière administration de l'ISS.

Composition destinée à être utilisée selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, où la modification de maladie à long terme dure au moins 13 semaines après la dernière administration de l'ISS.

Composition destinée à être utilisée selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, où le traitement conduit à une modification de maladie à long terme de l'asthme où l'asthme est l'asthme allergique.
Composition destinée à être utilisée selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, où l'ISS est l'ISS 1018.

Composition destinée à être utilisée selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1 à 10, où l'ISS est 5'-Nx(TCG(Nq))yNw(X1X2CGX2'X1'(CG)p)z où N sont des nucléosides avec x = 0-3, y = 1-4, w = -2, -1, 0, 1 ou 2, p = 0 ou 1, q = 0, 1 ou 2, et z = 1-20, où X1 et X1', X2 et X2' sont auto-complémentaires, et où la 5' T de la séquence (TCG(Nq))y est à 0-3 bases de l'extrémité 5' du polynucléotide.
Composition destinée à être utilisée selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, où l'ISS est une ISS non conjuguée.
Composition destinée à être utilisée selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, où l'ISS comprend des liaisons phosphorothioate.
